* Miran Z. <zlac53@...> [2007-05-16 13:50]:
> Well, looks like there exists that other "kind of state change"
> - the much anticipated book "RESTful Web Services" (preview
> chapter,
> http://www.oreilly.com/catalog/9780596529260/chapter/ch04.pdf,
> page 15) shed some light - it makes clear distinction between
> "application state" (living on client) and "resource state"
> (living on server and being identical for all clients). And it
> seems that both are equally important to REST.
> 
> Any thoughts/comments/suggestions?

I am still trying to get a grip on my thinking, but the point is
that state means a different thing for the server than for the
client. The client may keep implicit state that persists across
requests, but the server may not. State on the server is always
explicit, exposed via resources.

Thatâ€™s not a satisfactory explanation, but my understanding is
not yet coherent enough to express it much better than that.
